Project Objectives Detailed inspections of the Selingue hydropower facility carried and Description: out in 1993 and 1994, highlighted important occurrences which exist in particular in the earthen dikes of the dam. The main objective of the project is to repair and rehabilitate these facilities to avoid: (a) an important reduction in the generation capacity and its eventual stoppage; and (b) any risk for the security of the population downstream. Other objectives include: (a) maintaining electricity demand/supply balance by increasing, marginally, the thermal capacity of the system, and implementing an Energy Efficiency Program, (b) improving the capacity of EDM to properly operate, maintain, and supervise its power generation facilities; and (c) preparing the power sector long-term institutional and regulatory framework. The project would include: (a) civil works for the Selingue dam (base cost: US$7.6 million); (b) overhaul of the Selingue power plant and reinforcement of the thermal generation capacity (base cost: US$25.4 million); (c) consultant services for the supervision of works and various technical studies (base cost: US$2.8 million); (d) training for EDM's staff (base cost: US$1.4 million); and (e) materials, equipment and goods (base cost: US$3.3 million).
 ii Project Benefits: The Selingue power plant provides 70% of the electricity supplied by EDM. If this production ceases or is substantially reduced, all economic activities in the country would be dramatically affected. The project will prevent such a situation and will permit EDM, at a limited cost, to preserve assets the value of which is estimated at more than US$300.0 million. Project Risks: Given the tight demand/supply balance over the next four years, the main risk that could affect the proposed project implementation is related to EDM's ability to carry out the rehabilitation project within its strict schedule. However, this risk remains limited given that: (a) EDM's experience in project implementation has been enhanced in the context of the ongoing Power II Project; (b) EDM's overall management capacity is expected to substantially improve under the Management Contract which has been effective since January 1995. Beyond 1999, when the rehabilitation works are completed and the Management Contract is finished, the sound technical operation, monitoring, and maintenance of the Selingu6 facility will depend on the sustainability of the overall improved management capacity of EDM and on EDM's financial resources. The EDM training program and the new institutional and regulatory framework preparation, which are part of the project, will provide a basis to fulfill these conditions. It is also expected that, given the financial restructuring plan of EDM adopted by the GOM in 1995, the company will have sufficient resources to finance operation and maintenance costs in the future.  Republic of Mali Selingue Power Rehabilitation Project 1. THE ENERGY SECTOR A. Background 1.1 Mali is one of the largest countries in Africa, with a surface area of 1.24 million km2. The population is estimated at 9.5 million in 1994, with 80% living in rural areas. Of the eight main cities in Mali, only the capital, Bamako, with a population of about 800,000 inhabitants, is a major urban center. Mali is one of Africa's poorest countries, with a 1994 per capita GDP of US$250. The economy is largely dependent on agriculture, which is the primary source of income for most of the population and accounts for the largest share of product exports (primarily cotton). During the last five years, the Government of Mali (GOM) implemented a wide range of economic and sectoral policy reforms. The underlying objective has been to improve the competitiveness of the economy and lay the foundation for the sustained long-term growth needed to help raise the standard of living and alleviate poverty. These reforms have removed bottlenecks to private sector participation allowing the market forces to play a more important role in the determination of economic outcomes. The impact of these reforms is shown by the improvement in economic performance over the adjustment period. On January 12, 1994 the GOM, in consultation with the other member countries of the CFA zone, decided to strengthen its adjustment strategy. The fixed parity of the CFA Franc was changed from 50 to 100 CFAF per French Franc. B. Energy Resources and Consumption 1.2 Mali's domestic energy resources consist of biomass (fuelwood, charcoal, agricultural and agro-industrial residues), hydro, and solar energy. Presently, only biomass for household energy and hydro for electricity generation are exploited on a significant scale. The country's hydroelectric potential, based on the Senegal and Niger river system, is estimated at about 1,000 MW capable of producing 5,000 GWh in an average year. Of this potential, only about 50 MW (220 GWh) have been developed so far, at the Selingue and Sotuba dams on the Niger River. Mali has no significant known fossil fuels and petroleum product consumption is entirely dependent on imports (about 200,000 tons annually). 1.3 Final energy consumption is low and was estimated in 1992 at 1.83 mnillion tons of oil equivalent (toe). The energy balance for 1992 (Table 1) shows a consumption of 200 kg of oil equivalent per capita per year. Fuelwood and charcoal represent more than 88% of the consumption, whereas modern energy (petroleum products and electricity) represents less than 12%. Households represent about 90% of the total final energy demand, one of the world's highest relative shares. This indicates the low development of the modern economic sector and the limited access of the agricultural sector to petroleum and electricity.

Energy Sector Institutions and Policies 1.4 Responsibilities in the energy sector are distributed among various agencies and are rather complex: (a) the Ministry for Rural Development and Environment (MDRE) is in charge of managing Mali's forest resources and the supply of fuelwood; (b) petroleum product importation and distribution are entirely controlled by private operators but are regulated by the National Office for Petroleum Products (ONAP) under the supervision of the Ministry of Finance and Trade (MFC); (c) hydrocarbon exploration is left to oil companies but controlled by the Direction nationale de la geologie et des mines (DNGM), and (d) energy sector planning is under the responsibility of the Direction nationale de l'hydraulique et de l'energie (DNHE). These two departments (DNGM, DNHE) are part of the Ministry for Mines, Energy, and Hydraulics (MM4EH). 1.5 The main objectives of the GOM energy policy are: (a) to evaluate and develop domestic energy resources, and (b) to promote more efficient utilization of all forms of energy. To achieve these objectives, the GOM requested support from the World Bank/UNDP Energy Sector Management Assistance Program (ESMAP). Two important studies were subsequently carried out: an Energy Assessment (November 1991) and a Household Energy Strategy (November 1992). 1.6 In 1991, the GOM decided to totally liberalize pump prices, and to adopt a simplified system of tax collection at customs, incorporating into a single tax all of the previous taxation components. These measures resulted in increased competition and eventually led to some positive effects on petroleum production prices. However, this deregulated system needs to be monitored more effectively by the Government. This is the main objective of the newly created ONAP with particular emphasis on control of tax evasion, product quality and safety at distribution points. 1.7 The new household energy policy is mainly based on: (a) for the supply side, the rationalization of the transfer of the responsibility of the control and management of the natural forests from the state to the local rural communities and the implementation of urban woodfuel master plans and forest management plans; and (b) for the demand side, improving how household energy is utilized (revision of woodfuel pricing, interfuel substitution, promotion of improved wood stoves, etc.). This strategy is currently being implemented

Power Sector Institutions and Organization 2.1 Until recently, the power sector was poorly organized with responsibilities divided among several agencies. For example, the DNHE was in charge of planning and building major power and water schemes and of technical supervision of the sector; Energie du Mali (EDM) was the parastatal responsible for the operation and maintenance of most power and urban water facilities, including those constructed by DNH-E; and the Office pour 1'exploitation des ressources hydrauliques du Haut Niger (OERHN), another parastatal established in 1981, was responsible for the Selingue hydroelectric plant and for promoting irrigation and fishery activities. All of the electricity generated at Selingue was sold by OERHN to EDM. In addition to these agencies, the Organisation pour la mise en valeur du fleuve Senigal (OMVS), the regional river authority for the Senegal Basin, was created in 1972 by Mali, Mauritania, and Senegal. This agency built the Manantali dam in western Mali in 1988 to supply electricity to Mali, Senegal, and Mauritania. 2.2 This organization of the power sector led to several problems. These included: (a) poor coordination between DNHE, OERHN, and EDM for investment planning and system operation; (b) excessively high tariffs for the electricity sold by OERHN to EDM which drained the power sector of important financial resources to subsidize other sectors; and (c) poor operation and maintenance of the Selingue facility which contributed to the current critical condition of the dam (para 4.2). To address these institutional problems several actions where taken in beginning in 1988 and implemented, including the transfer of responsibility to EDM of: (a) the operation of the Selingue power facility, under a Management Contract with OERHN, and (b) the technical responsibility for planning and operation of all power facilities with the exception of regional and multipurpose projects (e.g., Manantali Regional Energy Project). However, these measures were not sufficient and did not address the need for eliminating the implicit subsidization of other sectors by the power sector. In April 1993, the GOM decided to go one step further and transfer all of the Selingue assets from OERHN to EDM. This decision materialized in September 1995 through a concession agreement. 2.3. In the long-term, the role of the state in the power sector will need to be revisited and the institutional framework and regulation system revised to promote a rapid and sustainable development of the sector and the access of a larger part of the population to electricity. Under the proposed project, the Government will prepare and adopt a new institutional framework based on studies and on systematic consultation with all of the stakeholders including power consumers. This will include the redefinition of the State's role; the role of the private participants in the power sector; and monopoly or competition between operators. During negotiations, agreement was reached that not later than three months prior to the mid-
 4 term review, in 1998, the GOM will furnish to IDA for its review an action plan for the strengthening of the framework of the power sector and thereafter take all measures necessary on its part for implementation of said action plan, taking into account IDA's comments (para 4.12 and 5.1) B. Existing Electricity Supply Facilities 2.4 The existing power network in Mali is shown on Map IBRD 27692. It comprises an interconnected power system with a capacity of about 70 MW and 10 isolated centers totaling 10 MW. Detailed characteristics of existing facilities are provided in Annex 1. The Selingue hydroelectric plant is by far the largest plant with an installed capacity of 44 MW and an annual energy generation of about 180 GWh (Annex 2). In Bamako, EDM also operates two plants, the Sotuba hydroelectric plant (5.2 MW, 39 GWh), and the Dar Salam diesel plant with an installed capacity of 18 MW. The isolated centers are supplied by diesel units varying in capacity from 35 kVA to 1,375 kVA, except for Kayes where the 500 kW Felou hydroelectric plant supplies part of the demand. In the context of the ongoing Power II Project, and through the financing from IDA (Credit 1998-MLI), Caisse frangaise de developpement (CFD) and Kreditansalt fir Wierderbau (KfW) almost all of these thermal plants have been rehabilitated and/or expanded, including the Dar Salam plant. Since 1993, detailed inspections and studies have shown that the Selingue dam is in critical condition, partly as a result of poor operation and maintenance practices (para 4.2). The proposed project has been specifically designed to address these problems. 2.5 The transmission grid comprises 350 km of 150 kV lines (130 km from Selingue to Bamako, 220 km from Bamako to Segou), 80 km of 66 kV line from Selingue to Yanfolila and 175 km of 30-kV lines forming a loop around Bamako and also supplying the towns of Koulikoro and Kalana. The transmission system is reasonably well maintained but its system of electrical protection is in poor condition. A study was carried out in 1994, financed under IDA credit 1998-MLI, to analyze possible improvements. As a result, a comprehensive US$3.1 million investment program was prepared and is part of the proposed project. In the 1980s, the distribution system (15 kV and low voltage lines and substations) in Bamako, as well as in the isolated centers, was not adequately maintained or extended. This resulted in the population's limited access to electricity, poor service reliability, and high energy losses (22%). Under the ongoing Power II Project (Cr. 1998-MLI), important rehabilitation/ extension programs are being implemented to address these problems. As a result, major improvements are foreseen in the near future in service reliability as well as a reduction in energy losses, and a significant increase in the population's access to electricity. C. Access to Service and Electricity Demand 2.6 In 1994, EDM had about 59,000 customers of which about 78% were in the Bamako area. About 44,000 are households but only 7% of the population has access to electricity compared to 31,000 and 4% in 1988. Even in Bamako, the capital city, with about 42,000 customers, the electrification rate is only 40%. From 1987 to 1994, EDM's electricity sales grew from 150 GWh to 209 GWh, with an average annual increase of 4.8% compared to 13%
 5 from 1981 to 1987, mainly because of supply limitations (generation capacity and distribution network). Demand studies (1993 tariff study, updated in 1995) show that there is considerable potential for electricity use. However, the demand/supply balance will continue to be tight over the next five years. Under the proposed project, the consumption growth rate is expected to be at 5% per year in 1996 and 1997, and 8% per year from 1998 to 2000. These figures result from an investment and rehabilitation program which will progressively remove the supply-side bottleneck (para 2.7). Beyond the year 2000, the strategy for power sector development and for increasing the access of the population to electricity would depend on the timely completion of new large supply sources (Manantali Regional Energy Project and the interconnection with the electrical system of C6te d'Ivoire). The forecast of electricity consumption and generation up to 2005 is provided in Annex 3. D. Investment Program 2.7 EDM, with the assistance of consultants, developed a least cost expansion plan for the Malian power system for the period 1995-2000. It includes: (a) the completion of the rehabilitation and extension program of the Bamako distribution system and the isolated centers, under the ongoing Power II Project, (b) the completion of the rehabilitation and extension program of the generation systems in the isolated systems under the Power II Project as well as under new CFD and KfW funded operations; (c) the addition of 9 MW of thermal capacity from 1996 to 1997 under the proposed project. The immediate priority is being given to repair/rehabilitate the country's main generation facility, at Selingue (paras 4.1 to 4.3). In the medium/long-term, after 1999/2000, the investments would consist of: (a) the Manantali power facility (200 MW, 800 GWh out of which at least 300 GWh could be sold to Mali); (b) the expansion of the transmission system (Manantali-Bamako; Segou-Sikasso- Koutiala-Bougouni); and, possibly (c) the interconnection with the C6te d'Ivoire transmission system. The total capital expenditure for the period 1995-2000 is estimated at US$161.0 million, excluding the Manantali Regional Energy Project. The detailed investment plan up to the year 2000, and tentatively for the period 2000-2004, is provided in Annex 3. E. Energie du Mali (EDM) Organization, Management and Staffing 2.8 EDM, established in 1961, is a semi-publicly owned enterprise with the GOM holding the majority (97.2%) of the shares and Electricite de France (EDF) the remaining (2.8%) shares. EDM is administered by a nine member board comprised of the Government (seven members), EDF (one member) and EDM staff (one member). EDM has its own training center (Centre de perfectionnement professionnel - CPP) and also sends staff for training to the Ecole superieure interafricaine d VlectriciW (ESEE) and the Centre des metiers de l 'dectricite (CME) in C6te d'Ivoire. 2.9 In spite of relatively important technical assistance programs during the past fifteen years, EDM's management still needs some support. In April 1993, the GOM decided on a
 6 more drastic solution by contracting out the management of EDM to a private professional partner for a period of four to five years (Delgation globale et temporaire de gestion - DGG). A consortium named SHEC, comprising Saur International, Hydro-Quebec International (HQI), EDF and CRC Sogema, was selected and has been managing EDM satisfactorily since January 1995. The fundamental objective is to enhance the management capacity of EDM. Some important characteristics of this Management Contract are the following: (a) it is a transitional solution until the GOM decides on and implements a new regulation and institutional framework for the power sector (paras 2.2 and 2.3); and (b) although all EDM's operational responsibilities have been entrusted to the private operator (current operation as well as investment), the legal status of EDM and its ownership remain unchanged. To address EDM's immediate needs, strong emphasis was put on: (a) streamlining procedures and management practices; and (b) upgrading EDM staffs professionalism by implementing a comprehensive training program. The achievement of these objectives will be evaluated on the basis of a financial and performance audit which will be carried out at the end of 1996, and for the following two (or three) years, specific measurable performance targets will be set up, and remuneration will be partially performance based. Accounting, Auditing, and Insurance 2.10 Until the end of 1994, EDM's accounting system was based, on accrual accounting principles of the 1957 French Chart of Accounts. These principles have not been properly followed because of EDM's technical and management weaknesses. Since January 1995, EDM has been using the 1982 French Chart of Accounts. 2.11 Since 1984, EDM's accounts have been audited by independent auditors acceptable to IDA. Because of the weaknesses indicated above, auditors have been unable to certify the accounts and have consistently issued a disclaimer of opinion. One of the main and immediate objectives of the Management Contract is to address this problem and have the FY96 accounts certified without qualification. 2.12 In 1994, with financing from IDA (Credit 1998-MNLl), a consulting firm carried out a full inventory and revaluation of EDM's assets. The report was submitted at the end of 1994, and EDM with the GOM is analyzing how to incorporate these results into its financial statements without disruptive fiscal effects. One of the objectives of this revaluation of fixed assets was to assess the adequacy of current insurance coverage and make corresponding adjustments. According to the study, EDM maintains insurance coverage against regular utility risks, but the insured amounts are insufficient. Agreement was reached during negotiations on: (a) annual audit of EDM's financial statements including the management letter; and (b) pro-forma revaluation of fixed assets and corresponding adjustments in insurance coverage (para 5.1).

The last tariff increase occurred in February 1994 (19%), following a study carried out under the Power II Project. This increase, however, was not sufficient to transfer the whole impact of the CFAF devaluation to the consumers. To address this, a new financial restructuring plan was set up in October 1995. The objective is
 8 to provide, for the next four to five years, an orderly and reasonable solution, which would limit tariff increases to the minimum required. 2.16 In this context the GOM made the following decisions: (a) Selingue facility was transferred to EDM as of January 1995 under a concession agreement, (b) some of EDM's debt to the GOM was written off (US$30.0 million), (c) EDM's investments would be exonerated of taxes and duties, at least during the entire period of the proposed project; and (d) the electricity tariff levels would be increased by 9%, from CFAF 70/kWh to CFAF 76/kWh by January 1998. This plan also takes into account substantial improvements in EDM's management performance under the current Management Contract. These improvements include a reduction in network losses from 22% to 16% in 1998 and a decrease in EDM's receivables from 246 days in 1994 to 70 days in 1998.  I1 IV. THE PROJECT A. Background 4.1 The hydroelectric dam of Selingue, commissioned in 1980, is located on the Sankarani river, a tributary of the Niger river. Its construction was financed by Arab donors, CFD, AfDB, FED, KfW and FAC for US$140.0 million. The main facilities include: (a) a dam consisting of two earthen dikes totaling 2,600 meters in length and 23 meters in height and a 334 meters long concrete dam between the dikes; a spillway flood with a maximum release capacity of 3,600 m3/s, and a reservoir of about 2 billion m3; (b) the power plant which comprises four 11.9 MW units; and (c) a single circuit 150 kV transmission line of 130 km from Selingue to Bamako. The annual average production is approximately 180 GWh representing over 70% of EDM's current electricity supply. 4.2 As part of the ongoing Power II Project, a detailed technical inspection was carried out in 1993 by an engineering firm. This study concluded that: (a) the monitoring of the different components of the dam and the power plant was inadequate and most of the auscultation equipment was out of service; and (b) some important deficiencies exist, both in the civil and electromechanical facilities. Additional studies were needed and carried out from mid-1993 to December 1994 to analyze the nature and the origin of the occurrences and to design remedial measures accordingly. These studies confirmed that worrisome phenomena were taking place regarding the earth dikes and in particular, that there was some seepage through the right abutment of the dike and through the dike itself. The experts indicated that this was a slow phenomenon, but that if not properly addressed, it could result in a sudden internal collapse of the dam and provoke a large failure in the dike. This would subsequently result in the loss of Mali's main power facility and possibly place the security of people living downstream at risk. During negotiations agreements was reached that an annual inspection of the dam will be carried out by qualified and independent experts and reports will be submitted to IDA (para 5.1). 4.3 The studies also concluded that: (a) there is an urgent need for a systematic overhaul of all electromechanical equipment; and (b) the transmission equipment component, although in relatively good condition, needs some maintenance and improvements (especially for electrical protection of the system). Inadequate and unclear sharing of responsibilities over the Selingue facility, involving OERHN and EDM, resulted in poor monitoring and maintenance of the main asset of the Malian power sector. The decision made by GOM to transfer all Selingue assets from OERHN to EDM will clarify these responsibilities and address this shortcoming. B. Environment 4.28 The project will have a positive effect on the environment since it aims at: (a) repairing and rehabilitating a deteriorating structure and strengthening the security of the dam; and (b) contributing to maintaining Mali's hydroelectric energy capacity thus reducing the amount of electricity generated by thermal units. It revealed a noticeable positive impact, in particular on the development of agriculture and fishing in surrounding areas. The study also showed that the construction of the Selingue dam has had negative impacts and that despite the initial mitigation plan which was prepared and implemented in the early 1980s,

J. Project Justification and Benefits 4.31 Repairs of the Selingue dam. Electricity supply is of vital importance to any country's economy. The Selingue power plant provides 70% of EDM's electricity. If this production ceases or is substantially reduced, all economic activities will be dramatically affected and may ultimately lead to a major crisis. The proposed project would prevent such a situation and permit at a limited costs, the preservation of assets the value of which is estimated at more than US$300.0 million. It would also avoid to place the security of people living downstream at risk. 4.32 The experts recommended that the repairs be undertaken immediately and that until June 1997, the maximum level of the reservoir be limited at 348.0 meters instead of a normal level of 348.5 meters. If the dam is not repaired, it will not be possible to go any further with the exploitation of the dam, even at a limited capacity. The alternative to rehabilitating the Selingue dam would be to abandon it and drain off the reservoir. The energy supply over the next 30 years (estimated economic remaining life time for the dam) would have to come from alternative sources. These could be: (a) a full thermal substitution (estimated cost US$185.0 million); or (b) a temporary thermal substitution from 1996 to 2000 which would then be replaced by energy purchased from the Manantali dam (estimated cost US$115.0 million). As shown below, these alternatives are three to four times more expensive than the proposed S&lingue rehabilitation project and the proposed project is thus the least cost option. This high return is not surprising since this is primarily a rehabilitation and not an investment project. Rehabilitating the Selingue Facility A. 1. Selingue: repairing the dam: The works consist of: (a) reinforcement of the embankment dam; (b) concrete facilities repairs; and (c) improvement of the monitoring devices and instrumentation system. The works are expected to start in July 1996 and be completed by September 1997. (a) Reinforcement of the embankment dam: the proposed measures will allow for the reinforcement of the stability of the dam and of the embankment. It consists of: (i) improving of draining facilities; (ii) repairs to the upper part of the upstream embankment crest; (iii) improving water-tightness of the contact zone between the right embankment and the right bank; and (iv) repairs to the road superstructure. (b) Repairs of the concrete structure: the works are very similar to ordinary maintenance works. They are comprised of the following: (i) the rehabilitation of the draining facilities; (ii) a comprehensive check-up of the foundations by drilling in appropriate locations; and (iii) the water-tightness of the contact zone between the embankments and the concrete structure, as well as the repairs of concrete cracks. (c) Improvement of the monitoring system and instrumentation: this system will monitor the structure of the dam and its precise deformations. This monitoring is based on measuring hydraulic pressure of the concrete facilities, the earth embankrnents, and the contact zones between them. A.2. Selingue: repairing the power plant: The component consists of: (a) the rehabilitation of the basic, general equipment of the powerhouse; and (b) a comprehensive overhaul of the four power generating units. The works are expected to start in July 1996, one unit would be repaired each year until 2000.
 40 Annex 6 Page 2 of 10 (a) General equipment of the power station: Including: (i) the rehabilitation of the measurement system and hydraulic monitonrng system; (ii) the renovation of the filtration system and the cooling system for the units, and (iii) the overhaul of the back-up existing diesel generator. (b) Renovation of the four generator units: the priority will be given to unit 4 which is in the most critical stage. For each unit, the following works will be implemented: (i) the overhaul of mechanical facilities of the turbines, (ii) the renovation of speed and voltage monitonng systems; and (iii) the overhaul and rehabilitation of the alternators: for this item, the precise contents of the works will not be known until the units are disassembled. A.3. Selingue, repairing the transmission lines: A.3.a. Selingue-Balingue Transmission Line: an expertise of these facilities was made in 1993. It confirmed that the 150 kV facilities are in good condition. However, some equipment must be replaced. It consists of: (a) The supply of security tools; the replacement of insulators; the rehabilitation of pylon protection features; and (b) The renovation of transformers and other equipment in the Selingue and Balingue substation. A.3.b: Setting of the Transmission Network Electrical Protections: includes the supply and installation of the necessary equipment to overhaul and rehabilitate the network electrical protection of the interconnected network for the different voltage levels: 150 kV, 30 kV and 15 kV. A.3.c: 15 kV Voltage Regulation in Balingue Substation: includes the supply and installation of a transformer to maintain and regulate the 15 kV voltage level at the Balingue substation and over the medium voltage distribution network. This would prevent the need to use the Selingue alternators for voltage adjustment. B. Maintaining the demand/supply balance B. 1. Reinforcement of the Thermal Power Capacity: Under this component, nine small additional diesel units of I MW each would be installed with the objective of later transferning them to isolated centers, when the Manantali dam is completed. B.2. Energy Efficiency Program: This component consists of studies and supply of goods to improve load management and electricity end-use efficiency. (a) The load management studies will provide recommendations to: (i) reduce the household and public building electricity consumption, (ii) limit the peak demand by appropriate tariff incentives, and (iii) reduce technical losses in the distribution network. (b) Supply of goods to implement the measures resulting from the studies.

The cost of these three scenarios are respectively US$48 rmillion (proposed project), US$115 million (thermal altenrative + purchase from Manantali), US$185 million (thermal altemative) and thus the proposed project is by far the least cost option. 3. The intemal rate of return for the overall Selingue rehabilitation was calculated by evaluating the cost of the lost energy if the dam was drained off. The current average sale price (CFAF 70/kWH) has been applied to the energy sold (energy produced minus technical and non-technical losses) and resulted in an average energy loss estimate of US$22 million per year. Thus, the Intemal Economic Rate of Retum (IERR) for the project is 66%, a result of comparing the project with the loss of energy over the remaining economic life of the dam.

In particular, the possibility of postponing these works and taking a greater risk of a breakdowvn of the units was evaluated. The project and its proposed timing ( scenario 1, 1996-1999) was compared to two other scenarios: - Scenario 2: Rehabilitation of the electromechanical facilities delayed after year 2000, after the Manantali plant completion. - Scenario 3: One-year delay on the proposed project (1997-2000). 5. In case of a unit breakdown, the costs involved are: (a) the cost of the replacement of the unit by new equipment (US$7 million: US$3.2 million for the alternator, US$3.8 million for the turbine) instead of the cost of its rehabilitation; and (b) the cost of the loss of energy during the time needed for its replacement (US$2.8 million: estimated at 20 GWh pear year, lasting 1.5 year, cost equal to the thermal cost of supply at US$0.092/kWh). In scenario 2, the rehabilitation of the four units would take place after year 2000 and so the thermal backup planned in scenarios I and 3 would not be needed. 6. The risks of breakdown of the units were assessed by the engineering firm in charge of the technical expertise of the dam. Probabilities of breakdown were given for each year and for each unit. Thus, the cost of each scenario was obtained by applying: (a) these probabilities to the cost of the energy loss and the cost of the replacement of the equipment; and (b) the complementary probabilities (probabilities of not having a breakdown and of being able to implement the repairs) to the cost of the proposed repairs. To simplifv calculations, the various components of the units (turbine, alternator, etc.) were considered as a whole and not as separate elements. Such a hypothesis can be regarded as legitimate given the fact that both alternators and turbines are in critical condition and have high probabilities of breakdown. 7. Probabilities as estimated by the engineer grow rapidly and reach, in 1999 before Manantali plant completion. 100% for the most damaged unit (unit 4). and close to 50% for the other units.  54 Annex 10 Page I of 2 Mali Selingue Power Rehabilitation Project Environmental Impact of the Rehabilitation Works and Mitigation Measures Summary I . The Selingue reservoir encompasses an area of 409 km2 at the normal water level which is 348.5m. After ten years of operation, a detailed study by an engineering consulting firm concluded that there was an urgent need for a systematic overhaul of the facilities after finding several deficiencies due partly to poor monitoring and maintenance. 2. The objective of the environmental study was to evaluate the impact of the proposed rehabilitation program. These works consist of: (a) the reinforcement of the embankment damr, (b) the concrete facilities repairs; (c) the improvement of the monitoring devices and instrumentation system; (d) the rehabilitation of the basic general powerhouse equipment; and (e) a comprehensive overhaul of the four power generating units. 3. According to the nature of the planned works, the area which has to be taken into consideration consists of the immediate vicinity surrounding the dam and neighboring areas where some needed raw materials will be extracted. 4. The results of the study include: (a) a description of the work to be undertaken, and (b) a presentation of the area in terms of its physical, biological, human, and water resources. Subsequently, the potential impact on the environment as a result of the rehabilitation of the Selingue facilities was identified and comprised several aspects: * the sand banks out of which the raw materials (stones, mud, sand) are extracted and the risks associated with this excavation. These may include vibration, noise, and dust and also the risk that water residue, created from the removal of these materials, may stagnate and become a breeding ground from which malaria and yellow fever may develop, * oil dumping, a risk derived from the dismantling of the alternators and turbines, may have a negative impact on the surrounding aquatic areas; * the risk of erosion along the banks of the created drainage channel, extending lOm on either side of the channel because of vegetation removal; * the risk of extreme traffic problems on the road which runs on the dam between the two banks of the river, as a result of depositing the stones of the protection wall,
 55 Annex 10 Page 2 of 2 the partial scraping of the hill and of the contact zone between the right embankment and the right bank, entails carrying out and treating a large volume of earth which may encumber and pollute the lake and the surrounding areas with harmful materials. 5. The proposed measures to reduce the above-cited impact should also focus on works planning in order to avoid injurious effects to villagers, the risks of dynamite (explosions should be kept to a distance) and the accumulation of rainfall which could create favorable conditions for insect larval development. 6. To avoid oil spillage, it was suggested that the contractor should be required to provide and use, as needed, absorbent material and protection film for the obstruction of the drain within the powerhouse. 7. To minimize the risk of soil erosion, it is necessary to quickly recreate the vegetation carpet in the zone surrounding the drainage channel. 8. To avoid the adverse effects on the transit capacity, the storage of the raw materials on the dike road by the contractors should be minimized. The surplus of raw materials should be returned to refill the extraction area.
 56 Annex I I Page I of 2 Mali Selingue Power Rehabilitation Project Environmental Assessment of Selingue Facilities Outline for a Mitigation Plan Summary l. The environmental assessment of Selingue facilities, since their construction in 1981, was carried out by an environmental consulting firm upon the request of the Energie du Mali (EDM). 2. After 14 years of operation, the Selingue facilities have had several noticeable effects on the physical and socio-economic environment of the surrounding area. These effects have materialized in several ways, which include: * Local Climate: there has been an improvement of the annual rainfall, according to the local population. * Hydrology and Energy: the positive impacts on the hydrological regime of the Sankarani river, which has been considerably modified, have been very important. These include: the potential for generation of about 200 GWh per year; a large reservoir of 2,166 million m3 which can be used for agricultural development; the rise of the water level which is very beneficial to agriculture and navigation on both the Sankarani and Niger rivers; and an improvement in the level of the phreatic water in the surrounding area of the reservoir. * Ecological Impacts: an important deforestation occurred, subsequent to: (a) the flooding of the reservoir (409 krn2); (b) the substantial clearing of land to reinstall some of the displaced population, and (c) the building of roads, paths, and the electricity transmission line to Bamako. This has not been sufficiently compensated by the slow natural regeneration sustained by the reservoir. The intensive commercial exploitation of forestry products has magnified this problem. Concerning aquatic flora and fauna, the general trend has been, meanwhile, to reinforce the local biodiversity (appearance of new species: Polygonum, Echinochloa; the number of fish species also rose from 42 in 1981 to 86 in 1995). The terrestrial fauna migrated towards more quiet zones after their native habitat was disturbed. The soil along the reservoirs has been more frequently flooded and remains almost permanently saturated. * Sociological Aspects: In this arena, there have been several marked changes: (a) the organization and responsibilities of the farmers have been strengthened; (b) health infrastructures have been built; (c) the migration of the youth has been reduced; and (d) the traditional leadership system has been weakened particularly because of the rapid monetarization and the development of juvenile delinquency.
 57 Annex 11 Page 2 of 2 * Economical Aspects: the impact of the Selingue hydroagricultural and electrical facilities on the development of the Mali's economy has been considerable. At the local level, the impact on the immediate area surrounding the facilities has varied from sector to sector. There has been positive effects such as: (a) in the agricultural sector, a 1,200 ha irrigation perimeter has been developed which led to the creation of several plantations, the promotion of agricultural markets, and to the creation of temporary jobs, particularly for women; (b) in the fishing sector, fish production rose from 600 kg before the dam was built to nearly 4,000 tons in 1994 and this has subsequently increased the number of activities linked to fishing such as ice production, fish processing, and transportation of fish to Bamako. However, there has also been negative effects including: (a) the reduction of agricultural land, the loss of fruit plantations, the reduction of the harvest of Vittelanra paradoxa, Parkia biglobosa, and trees; and (b) the flooding of several sites of gold exploration (Makandiana, Tanga, Dodala, Kondjigula). - Health Aspects: Some negative impacts on the health of population continue to be important although mitigation measures have been implemented. Several diseases remain widespread in the area (e.g. schistosomiases rose from 0.9-3.2% in 1980 to 25-45% in 1995, malaria 32% in 1980 to 75% in 1995). There have been, however, some positive impacts on the health situation in the area as a result of the overall improvement of population's nutrition due to agricultural development, greater access to potable water, and the creation of health infrastructures. 3 . To minimize the negative consequences that were identified, the study has proposed the following additional mitigation measures: * to improve the standard of living of the local population by increasing access to running water and electrification; * to improve the conditions for the development of agriculture through increased land preparation and technical support; * to improve water resource management by better taking into account the needs for agriculture, the constraints of the fishing sector, and by regulating the various activities in the reservoir area; * to ensure a better monitoring of the reservoir; an alarm system, against soil erosion around the lake, should be implemented; * to ensure a sustainable management of the natural resources surrounding the reservoir: reforestation and regulation for firewood utilization, information and education of the population should be promoted; and finally * to reinforce the local health plan, at the school and the community level, the resources of the Centre de Sante de Selingue should be enhanced.

doc.abstracts: The main objective of the Selingue Power Rehabilitation Project is to repair and rehabilitate the Selingue facility to ensure that the major source of electricity supply is not destroyed. Other objectives of the project are to: 1) maintain the electricity demand-supply balance by increasing the thermal capacity of the system and implementing an energy efficiency program; 2) improve the capacity of Energie du Mali (EDM) to properly operate, maintain and supervise its power generation facilities; and 3) prepare a long-term institutional framework and regulatory system for the power sector and implement it as of 1999. The project consists of the following components: 1) rehabilitation of Selingue hydropower facility including dam, power plant and transmission system; 2) maintenance of the demand/supply balance which comprises the reinforcement of the thermal capacity and an energy efficiency program; 3) strengthening of EDM's management capacity; and 4) long-term institutional framework.
